summary: Migrate from internal Table component to ui-kit's version
root_cause_details:
The Revolut Business Frontend job generates an artifact that is later deployed. Artifacts generated from branches are intended for the development environment, while artifacts generated from the master branch are used for production deployment.

Typically, the name of the generated artifact includes both the branch name and the commit hash. However, for the biz-frontend, this naming convention was overridden to include only the commit hash, as part of a previous fix addressing another incident where the production deployment was accidentally broken for the web team.

This change introduces the risk of generating a development artifact with the same name as the production artifact generated by the master branch.

Since all artifacts are stored in the same Google Cloud (GC) bucket, if two artifacts with identical names are generated - one from development and one from production - the latest artifact will overwrite the previous one.

summary: core-auth: Require access token expiry to be present and not exceed 3 months

Identity & Auth team realised there is ongoing issue only after being approached by other team (Junior).

 Root cause #3
Core Auth API neither requires setting expiry when issuing a new access token, nor validates the ranges of provided expiry.
This is a technical debt (probably from the beginnings of the project) that nobody on the team was aware of / paid attention to.


Root cause #4
Teams (including Junior) have been creating access tokens either without expiry, or with expiry long into the future.
Even though it’s core-auth API that shouldn’t allow for this, this is a point that requires actions, as it poses security concerns.

summary: 2024-06-21 (Android events tracking failure) - Outstanding Actions
root_cause_details:
Events tracking library was failing while initialization.

Why was it failing?

The network library uses reflection to instantiate actual network transport specific for Android. The class was not found due to a missing constructor.

Why was the constructor removed?

Code minification (R8) removed as it was unable to detect all indirect usages. Optimizations become more  aggressive after PMNG-4480: Android: Enable R8 full mode ~7Mb
DONE
 

Why didn’t we notice the error when it was introduced?

It is reproducible only in release builds with minification. 

Why don’t we use minification for non-release builds?
It was silently dropped by Google for debug builds in a recent update of build tooling (Google Issue Tracker). Re-enabling it was planned already, but not completed yet (see action items below).

Why didn’t we detect the error when the application was in beta?

This error was not reported as expected (evidence). In the first day it was happening in two devices/users and automation missed it. In next days, the error was considered as not new and the logic missed such a scenarios. See action items.

Why do we use non-fatal errors?

Tracking works in a non-blocking manner by design to not fail the application in case of unexpected issues. All known previous errors were about edge-cases for specific screens or events. This is why fail-fast in production was considered as undesired behaviour.

All such errors are reported as non-fatal events. They are more false-positive and noisy by nature, BUGS are not created automatically and reporting has higher thresholds.
